channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Lineker backs Rashford over school meals
item.description: The Prime Minister faces a growing rebellion among Tories who insist he should be extending the scheme for 1.3million vulnerable children for six weeks.

item.title: New Zealand confirms two NEW cases of coronaviru days after it 'eliminated' COVID-19
item.description: The two infections on Tuesday, both acquired during recent travel to the UK, ended a 24-day streak of no new infections in the country.

item.title: Kate and Gerry McCann hit back at German prosecutor's claims
item.description: The parents said: 'The widely reported news that we have a received a letter from the German authorities that states there is evidence or proof that Madeleine is dead is FALSE.'

item.title: Met Office issues severe weather warning for thunderstorms and flooding
item.description: Downpours could cause flooding this afternoon in a huge weather front across the west of the country stretching from Cornwall to Glasgow and parts of Northern Ireland.

item.title: Mayor slammed for comparing Black Lives Matter protesters to monkeys climbing on a car
item.description: Councillor Peter Kraus claimed he only found out about the post when he was contacted by the Pembroke Dock Town Council clerk amid accusations of racism.

item.title: Queen misses out on Royal Ascot visit for first time...
item.description: More than 300,000 guests, dressed in their finery, usually gather for the five-day sporting and social highlight in Berkshire, including the monarch (pictured during the 2019 carriage procession).
item.media:description: The Queen in her carriage at Royal Ascot in 2019 (Steve Parsons/PA)

item.title: Labour's Lisa Nandy demands Foreign Office remove five giant 'racist' British Empire murals
item.description: The pieces by Sigismund Goetze include images of empire seen as problematic by campaigners, including a representation of Africa as a little boy surrounded by white Anglo-Saxon adults.

item.title: Ex-student nurse, 27, is jailed for making bogus emergency calls
item.description: Sharna Dixon, 27, from Sheerness, Kent, pictured, was jailed for two years after admitting assaulting a police officer and making hundreds of fake emergency calls.

item.title: China's war robot 'Sharp Claw I' is armed with a machine gun and night vision
item.description: The remote-control machine, described as 'small but lethal', is designed to travel through complicated terrains at a fast speed and replace human soldiers in dangerous missions.

item.title: Flop cat! Hilarious moment Simba the kitten tries to leap on top of a fridge but falls VERY short
item.description: Simba the six-month-old kitten bit off more than he could chew after trying to jump to the top of a fridge from the edge of a kitchen counter in Dunsborough, West Australia.

item.title: Feminist writer blasts Amazon Prime for promoting 'crass' 70s British porn films to viewers
item.description: London-born feminist Kate Smurthwaite told FEMAIL that these films routinely present sexual harassment as a 'hilarious joke' and send a negative message about appropriate behaviour.

item.title: Statue defenders stand in front of sculpture of writer George Eliot during Black Lives Matter demo
item.description: A group of men, including veterans, stood guard over the George Eliot statue in Nuneaton, Warwickshire, just yards away from a BLM protest on Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Video game developed to help children with ADHD control their symptoms given FDA approval
item.description: The game is called EndeavorRX by developers Akili Interactive and is aimed at improving the attention of children aged eight to 12 diagnosed with ADHD.

item.title: Tyson Fury blasts Anthony Joshua's 'bull****' Black Lives Matter speech
item.description: Joshua, the IBF, WBA, WBO and IBO world heavyweight champion, was heavily criticised after addressing protesters in his hometown of Watford earlier this month.

item.title: More than NINE MILLION jobs are now being propped up by furlough scheme
item.description: The numbers covered by the massive furlough bailout have risen by another 200,000 in the past week to 9.1million, with the value of the claims nearing £21billion.

item.title: Romantic beauty spot in Exmoor that inspired Victorian novel Lorna Doone
item.description: The charity bought the nine acre site on the border of Devon and Somerset for £1.5 million shortly before coronavirus lockdown measures were introduced in March.

item.title: Novichok police officer Nick Bailey hits back at 'negativity' aimed at his wife
item.description: Detective Sergeant Nick Bailey publicly defended his wife Sarah after her portrayal in the second episode of the hit BBC series 'The Salisbury Poisonings', which aired on Sunday night.

item.title: Church will remove 'Chocolate covered C**n' headstone of blackface dancer GH Elliott
item.description: GH Elliot's headstone, and that of another singer who performed in blackface in the 1930s, were covered up last week at St Margaret's church in Rottingdean, east Sussex.

item.title: 'Crying' donkey being driven to a slaughterhouse 'desperately kowtows' to passersby
item.description: The heartbreaking video taken in north-eastern China shows the poor animal repeatedly bowing its head while being strapped at the back of a truck, seemingly with tears in its eyes.

item.title: Crown Princess Madeleine of Sweden celebrates her son Nicolas's fifth birthday
item.description: Mother-of-three Princess Madeleine of Sweden, 38, posted a new official portrait of the youngster to her official Instagram account yesterday with a touching message.

item.title: Fury as Munira Mirza 'who doesn't believe in structural racism' appointed to set up race commission
item.description: The choice of Munira Mirza, the head of the Prime minister's policy unit and a former deputy mayor from his time in charge of London, sparked uproar from campaigners and Labour MPs.

item.title: Spies and hackers can eavesdrop on conversations from 80 feet away by watching light bulbs
item.description: The 'lamphone' technique discovered by security experts from Israel needs only a laptop and gear - including a telescope and sensor - costing less than just £1,000.

item.title: Soldiers take to the streets of Dijon to restore calm as Chechen gangs open fire
item.description: Military reinforcements were flooding into Dijon after videos released on social media show well-armed masked men - who also brandish pistols - in the eastern city, 200 miles from Paris.

item.title: Woman sparks a discussion about lifestyle habits to leave in the past
item.description: An anonymous woman from the UK, told Mumsnet that she's been reflecting on her lifestyle habits during lockdown, and said that she won't be spending as much on clothes her kids grow out of.

item.title: London becomes the first region in England to see deaths fall BELOW average
item.description: The Office for National Statistics revealed that the week between May 30 and June 5 in the capital was the first time any region has recorded below-average deaths since March.

item.title: Pret A Manger launch a heat me at home range
item.description: The commuter's favourite coffee chain Pret a Manger is now available for delivery through Deliveroo, Uber Eats and Just Eat across the UK for orders of less than £30.

item.title: Mother-of-two science teacher, 39, drowned when BMW hit pool of water and flipped into River Trent
item.description: Mother-of-two Emma Fegan, 39, hit a pool of water in her BMW and her car flipped off the road and into the nearby River Trent in Nottinghamshire, an inquest heard.

item.title: Pilot who died when US Air Force F-15C fighter jet crashed in the North Sea is named
item.description: The US Air Force said1st Lt Kenneth Allen arrived at the 48th Fighter Wing at RAF Lakenheath in Suffolk earlier this year and is survived by his wife and parents.

item.title: High Streets across England saw 50% rise in shoppers yesterday
item.description: Data from Springboard up until 5pm yesterday showed footfall in retail parks that comprise high street retailers in England was up 33.4 per cennt while in shopping centres it rose by 34.1 per cent.

item.title: Murder investigation after woman, 37, is found dead and 33-year-old man is arrested
item.description: A murder investigation has been launched after a woman, 37, was killed on Monday night. Police were called to Russell Street, Kettering, to reports of disorder. A 33-year-old man has been arrested.

item.title: Two Michelin-starred restaurant The Ledbury in London's Notting Hill will not reopen after lockdown
item.description: The Ledbury in Notting Hill, which has two Michelin stars and regularly features among the top ranked eateries in the world, has 'no route to reopening'.

item.title: Beijing back in lockdown: Parts of the city are fenced off and new travel bans introduced
item.description: Parts of Beijing have been fenced off after a new outbreak of the coronavirus, believed to have stemmed from the Xinfadi wholesale food market, has caused 106 new Covid-19 cases.

item.title: Mother and daughter outraged over supermarket crop top ban
item.description: Chantell Humphreys, 46, and her 18-year-old daughter Isabelle were both wearing 'crop tops' when they visited the Asda store in Broadstairs, Kent on Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Happy kid! Toddler bursts into giggles every time baby goats bleat in adorable encounter
item.description: The bleating of two baby goats was enough to cause uncontrollable fits of giggles from two-year-old Ray Berger. The footage was filmed while his family were visiting relatives in Myerstown, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect Brueckner is investigated over rape and murder of 13-year-old German boy
item.description: In 1998, 13-year-old Tristan Brubach (pictured), was brutally murdered in Frankfurt, Germany. Christian Brueckner, the man suspected of killing Maddie, is now under investigation.

item.title: Lions roar again as Emma Weymouth opens Longleat safari park
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: From Thursday, everyone will be welcomed, although Emma emphasises that the reopening will be monitored.

item.title: Luke Horsfield left with severe scarring after £1,250 botched hair transplant surgery
item.description: Luke Horsfield, 26, an IT technician from Bradford, was worried about his thinning hairline and found a clinic in Turkey which would perform a transplant for half the price it would be in the UK.

item.title: Father's Day gift guide: Femail reveals the BEST gifts
item.description: FEMAIL has found the best presents available to buy online across a range of categories including food and drink, health and fitness and gifts for the house and garden.

item.title: Ant Middleton issues an apology for labelling BLM movement 'absolute scum' in now-deleted tweet
item.description: The SAS: Who Dares Wins star, 39, has issued an apology for labelling the Black Lives Matter movement 'absolute scum' in a video shared to Twitter on Monday.

item.title: Lord Hague tells Boris Johnson to listen to Tony Blair and roll-out Covid testing on 'massive scale'
item.description: The grim jobs data emerged as former Conservative leader William Hague demanded the two-metre rule is dropped.

item.title: Swimmers face strict rules when pools reopen after months on lockdown
item.description: Swim England, the sport's governing body, said the guidelines focus on 'reducing the risk of Covid-19 transmission within the swimming pool environment'.

item.title: Artificial intelligence can help track down invasive plants before they take over verges
item.description: The UK Centre for Ecology and Hydrology and Birmingham-based firm Keen AI are building the system to quickly survey areas like roadsides for invasive plant species.

item.title: Mother, 24, found out she had a rare form of cancer 48 hours before giving birth
item.description: Poppy Stewart-Brown, 24, from Cuckfield, West Sussex, suffered headaches and nosebleeds during her pregnancy with her daughter, but told these were common side effects.

item.title: Greggs will reopen 800 stores for takeaways from Thursday
item.description: Bosses unveiled the new-look stores across the UK, with floor markings, protective clothes for staff and screens at counters among measures to protect against coronavirus spreading.

item.title: Police officer bitten trying to break up lockdown-breaching party
item.description: Police responded to call about an assault and found a gathering of 30 people, a breach of the lockdown rules, at a house in Bethesda. Nerys Williams resisted police when they arrested her.

item.title: Radical report to call for ban on gambling advertisements in sport
item.description: All gambling advertising in sport should be banned, according to radical proposals put forward to the Government by an influential group of MPs. A year-long inquiry has been concluded.

item.title: Thousands call for Captain Cook statue to be REMOVED over his links to 'colonialism and genocide'
item.description: The statue in Cairns has attracted controversy over the British Royal Navy captain's treatment of Aboriginal people when his ship landed in Australia.

item.title: Princess Victoria poses for portraits with Prince Daniel on their 10th wedding anniversary
item.description: Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden, 42, posed for a series of stunning portraits alongside Prince Daniel, 46, at Gustav III's pavilion at Haga, as they celebrated their 10th wedding anniversary.

item.title: Marks and Spencer delight fans with launch of vegan 'avoca-dough' bread
item.description: M&S says its new 'avocadough' buns are perfect for a summer barbecue, and taste like a classic brioche. The buns cost £1.15 for a pack of two and are made with avocado and coconut oil.

item.title: Teen, 19, reveals he's spent £10,000 trying to live like it's the 1940s
item.description: Charlie Roy, 19, from Milton Keynes, believes his obsession with the wartime period was sparked by listening to his nan recount stories about working in an egg factory when he was a boy.

item.title: Three Indian soldiers are killed in fighting with Chinese forces along disputed Himalayan border
item.description: The Indian army said in a statement on Tuesday that a 'violent faceoff' took place in Galwan valley in the Ladakh region on Monday night 'with casualties on both sides.'

item.title: Sky Sports WON'T keep screening free Premier League matches once football returns to normality
item.description: Sky will show 64 of the remaining 92 Premier League matches this season with 25 on their free-to-air channel Pick. This includes Sunday night's Merseyside derby.

item.title: Terrifying moment kayaker is left stranded underneath waterfall after his boat gets stuck on a rock
item.description: Four kayakers made it safely down the falls in San Luis Potosi, central Mexico. But the fifth got caught by a protruding rock with his head under the water, and his friend had to help him jump free.

item.title: Loneliness makes it harder to quit smoking, study finds
item.description: Long periods of loneliness, such as those experienced during the current coronavirus lockdown, makes smoking habits worse, according to a new study.

item.title: Tony Godfrey who died in care home without living relatives is revealed as motorbike racing champion
item.description: Tenacious Tony Godfrey passed away in a care home in Bournemouth last December without a will or any known relatives to inherit his £30,000 estate.

item.title: Two-metre rule has NO basis in science, leading scientists say amid calls to drop the measure
item.description: Professors at the University of Oxford said there is little evidence to support the restriction after reviewing a World Health Organisation paper on the contentious topic.

item.title: Napoleon-obsessed historian shot student lover four times and dismembered her, court hears
item.description: Professor Oleg Sokolov, 64, shot Anastasia Yeschenko, 24, during a furious Champagne-fuelled domestic row. He then dumped her body parts in the Moika River in St Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: A statue to be proud of! People share photos of heartwarming monuments that 'enhance surroundings'
item.description: Historian James Barr, from London, urged Twitter users to share monuments they believe 'enhance their surroundings'. FEMAIL brings you some of the best from across the globe.

item.title: Spain threatens to quarantine Britons unless UK government drops own rule
item.description: Madrid has warned that 'reciprocal' coronavirus controls will be placed on travellers despite the country opening up to most of the rest of Europe from this weekend.

item.title: London-born 'computer genius' who died from leukaemia aged 15 moves closer to becoming a saint
item.description: Carlo Acutis, who was born to Italian parents in London, passed away in 2006 after contracting leukaemia. Six years later a Brazilian boy was cured from a rare disease after prayers to Carlo.

item.title: Mother speaks of her fight to have the deceased father of her twins put on their birth certificate
item.description: Grace Lewis, 26, from Romford, Havering, told FEMAIL of her sadness that her late partner Billy Townsend, 24, never got to meet their twins, now 18 months, after he was struck by a train and killed.

item.title: Day two of mandatory face-coverings on public transport descends into farce
item.description: The man was pictured on a Tube in London wearing the face covering over his eyes, as the government's new law making face coverings mandatory on public transport descended into a farce.

item.title: Are we set for soaring inflation or deflation? Either way, gold looks a good bet for investors
item.description: We ask whether inflation or deflation is the greater risk in the coming months and years and whether gold is a sensible option for investors looking to diversify.

item.title: Private detective who was murdered with an axe 'hated' man suspected of conspiring to kill him
item.description: Channel 4's Murder in the Carpark explores the unsolved killing of Daniel Morgan, who was found with an axe embedded in his face outside the Golden Lion pub, in Sydenham in 1987.

item.title: Ancient 17-foot longboat is discovered buried in mud at the edge of Irish lake
item.description: Cathal McDonagh found the boat when he walked down to a lake near Lisacul, County Roscommon. Dry weather had caused its water level to drop, revealing the ancient boat.

item.title: David Schwimmer's 'non-conformist' daughter Cleo, 9, gets head shaved
item.description: It was the 53-year-old Friends alum's ex-wife Zoë Buckman, who did the honors on their third grader

item.title: Donald Trump claims U.S. would have fewer coronavirus cases if it stopped testing
item.description: President Donald Trump blamed a rise in coronavirus cases on the increased testing being done, saying if it stopped, 'we'd have very few cases, if any.'

item.title: Are homes going back on sale with higher asking prices after lockdown?
item.description: I found a property for sale that was available last October with an asking price of £1.75million. It didn't sell and is now back on the market for £50,000 more.

item.title: Buggi website allows parents to rent buggies instead of buy
item.description: A duo say they can help parents prevent splashing out a fortune on a new buggy, only to want to change it a few months later - by offering them to rent instead.

item.title: North Korea 'blows up' liaison office with South after Kim Jong Un sister threatened military action
item.description: An explosion was heard and smoke (pictured) seen rising from the North Korean border city of Kaesong on Tuesday, near where the North-South liaison office is located.

item.title: Topple the Racists says 'colonial warmonger' Sir Arthur 'Bomber' Harris should be removed
item.description: English Heritage has asked for advice on how to protect its statue of Sir Arthur 'Bomber' Harris in London. Sir Arthur was the RAF Commander-in-Chief who oversaw bombing raids in Germany.

item.title: New British green number plates could allow drivers to use bus lanes and park for free
item.description: Drivers of electric cars are to be given green number plates that could allow them to use bus lanes and park for free.

item.title: Jaguar Land Rover slashing another 1,100 jobs
item.description: The car maker said it would cut the agency worker jobs as part of plans to save £5billion. Its finances have been squeezed after the pandemic forced its plants and showrooms to close.

item.title: Jaguar Land Rover slashing another 1,100 jobs
item.description: The car maker said it would cut the agency worker jobs as part of plans to save £5billion. Its finances have been squeezed after the pandemic forced its plants and showrooms to close.

item.title: As more patients seem to be surviving infection, John Naish asks: has Covid-19 burned itself out?
item.description: JOHN NAISH: Nearly three months into Britain's coronavirus pandemic and death and infection rates are falling steadily. Elsewhere in the world, there are as yet few signs of a 'second wave'.

item.title: EastEnders' Dean Gaffney flouts lockdown rules as he joins 40 revellers to party with strippers
item.description: While current rules prohibit mass gatherings amid the lockdown, the actor was seen mingling in the crowd as he soaked up the festivities in Huddersfield - more than 200 miles from his Essex home.

item.title: Bizarre 'face bra' which claims to get rid of double chins with NO EXERCISE wins over a legion of fa
item.description: The slimming-device from Australia-based Face Bra, which ships internationally, and has gone viral on Facebook, claims to 'get rid of your double chin' when it's worn every other day for forty minutes.

item.title: Grooming victim of former hockey player Tom Squires says 'he ruined my life'
item.description: Charlotte Flanigan was just 13 when former Sheffield Steelers hockey player Tom Squires started to groom her. With the paedophile up for parole later this year, Charlotte has shared her story.

item.title: Oxford University students impacted by George Floyd's death can apply for mitigating circumstances
item.description: The announcement followed pressure from campaigners at Oxford University who claim the horrific video of George Floyd's last moments had a lasting impact on black students.

item.title: Publishing staff revolt over JK Rowling's views on gender
item.description: At publishing house Hachette, several of those involved in Miss Rowling's new children's book, The Ickabog, are said to have staged their own rebellion during a heated meeting

item.title: NHS 'is heading back to normal' after UK's COVID-19 death toll fell by almost 70% in last fortnight
item.description: Falling coronavirus cases and low death rates mean the NHS is close to being able to resume its normal services, experts say. 38 recorded in the UK yesterday bringing the total to 41,736.

item.title: Trump's niece's tell-all book will offer a 'firsthand' look at the 'toxic family that made him'
item.description: Mary Trump, 55, has written a tell-all book, Too Much And Never Enough. It is due out in August to coincide with the Republican National Convention.

item.title: Couple find an amusing DIY tip from the previous owner of their house after stripping wallpaper
item.description: Charlotte Morrison, of London, shared a photo of the DIY tip she and husband Yariden discovered beneath the wallpaper in their lounge to Facebook - and was contacted by a relative.

item.title: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: If hordes of shoppers are free to mob Primark, why can't they go back to work?
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: The first thought that occurred to me as I saw the crowds queuing to get into shops yesterday morning was: Why aren't they at work?

item.title: Why changing sleeping position can beat back pain...so which of these tricks really work?
item.description: Journalist Antonia Hoyle searched for tips, techniques and gadgets that claim to help prevent stomach sleeping and, with the help of experts, put them to the test.

item.title: Teenagers whose parents are too strict struggle with social relationships later in life, study finds
item.description: Researchers from the University of Virginia found that children with overbearing and controlling parents at 13 also have trouble with educational attainment by age 32.

item.title: Disgraced ex-MP Fiona Onasanya slams Kellogg's for using a MONKEY as mascot for Coco Pops
item.description: Former Peterborough MP Fiona Onasanya emailed Kellogg's UK office for clarification on why Rice Krispies have 'three white boys' as a mascot whereas Coco Pops is represented by a monkey.

item.title: Wearing face masks saved 66,000 people in New York City and 78,000 in Italy from catching COVID-19
item.description: A new study, led by Texas A&M University, found that requiring that people wear face masks reduced the number of coronavirus infected more than 144,000 infections in Italy and New York City.

item.title: The Queen thanks royal supporters for their birthday well-wishes in a thoughtful letter
item.description: The Queen has thanked well-wishers for their support during the coronavirus crisis in a letter sent from Windsor Castle, shared to Instagram by a royal fan account.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... Britain goes shopping again
item.description: 'Mum SAID she'd shop until she dropped'

item.title: California gym reopens using pods for fitness fanatics to exercise in social distancing rules
item.description: A California gym has come up with a novel idea of keeping people apart South Bay Fitness in Redondo Beach have constructed nine 'workout pods' made out of plastic pipes and shower curtains.

item.title: Trump tries to stop John Bolton's book by saying ex-aide fill face 'criminal problems
item.description: John Bolton's first interview about his blockbuster book will be a primetime sit-down with ABC News' Martha Raddatz that will air Sunday night.

item.title: How coronavirus can attack the brain
item.description: British experts are starting to warn of a second wave of serious neurological woes involving lasting damage to the brain and nerves as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Children 'better prepared against Covid-19 as they get more colds which are caused by coronaviruses'
item.description: Children are better protected against coronavirus as their bodies are used to getting multiple colds, according to scientists. The common cold is caused by four harmless coronaviruses.

item.title: Sisters, aged 12 and 14, crushed to death after brick pillar their hammock was tied to collapsed
item.description: Scout Scaravilli, 14, and Chasey Scaravilli, 12, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, were at their home, lying in a hammock tied between a tree and a brick pillar, Sunday at about 7.45pm, when the pillar collapsed.

item.title: How risky is your operation?
item.description: As the rate of Covid-19 continues to decline, patients are now facing the unnerving prospect of being told their operation is now more risky than it once was.

item.title: Urgent appeal as little girl is found wandering the streets in Brent
item.description: A little girl who was found wandering the streets of Wembley alone on Monday evening has been reunited with her family. More than 1,100 people shared an appeal to help the youngster yesterday.

item.title: Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick admits giving green light to £1bn development helped Tory donor
item.description: Robert Jenrick admitted he knew he was saving Tory donor Richard Desmond tens of millions of pounds in approving a £1billion property scheme.

item.title: The image that proves good men really can change the world
item.description: SARAH VINE: He is not just carrying his enemy to safety; he is holding a far more precious burden: the weight of sorrow of a troubled world and the hopes of the silent majority.

item.title: Yes, he's had a tough time but Boris Johnson must be bolder - or the outlook is grim
item.description: STEPHEN GLOVER: If this country is to prosper again, we need that old Boris to shake off his demons, recover his brio and his health, and take control.

item.title: Privacy row erupts over plan to log thousands of innocent Britons' DNA on controversial EU database
item.description: The Home Office has risked a privacy backlash after announcing it would share DNA samples of those never charged with offences with European forces.

item.title: Will I ever be able to bend my thumb again? DR MARTIN SCURR answers your health questions
item.description: DR MARTIN SCURR: Trigger finger occurs when the tendon that helps to move or flex the finger catches in the sheath it runs through.

item.title: Antibody drug shows promise for treating severe COVID-19 patients
item.description: Eleven out of 12 severely or critically ill coronavirus patients given lenzilumab at the Mayo Clinic were discharged from the hospital in an average of five days, without side effects, new data shows.

item.title: Would you volunteer to be infected with Covid-19?
item.description: Four weeks ago, Oscar Tarpey, 21, an insurance worker from Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, volunteered to risk his own life by signing up to clinical trials for a vaccine to prevent coronavirus.

item.title: Bird lovers in lockdown are asked to avoid helping 'abandoned' fledglings
item.description: The RSPB said it cares for more than 1,000 fledglings every year that normally do not need their help. Although the youngsters may be sitting on the ground, a parent is usually nearby.

item.title: Golden State Killer suspect Joseph James DeAngelo Jr, 74, 'avoids death penalty under proposed deal'
item.description: Golden State Killer suspect Joseph James DeAngelo Jr, who is already 77 would live out the rest of his life in prison and avoid a death sentence under a proposed plea deal.

item.title: Fly-tippers beware... don't mess with me! Step forward one very plucky lady who snapped at two men
item.description: Andrea Good has a 'very feisty' temper, is a 'very strict' mother to her three children, is 'upfront and straight up' and appears to keep her IT contractor husband Rob on his toes at all times.

item.title: Soccer teammates score one last goal in honor of American boy, 16, killed in Mexico
item.description: The American teen, who was shot dead by a police officer in Mexico, was sent off with his last goal in a touching tribute by his soccer teammates.

item.title: Rayshard Brooks death: Officer was 'close to letting incident go'
item.description: Bodycam footage reveals Officer Devin Brosnan considered letting the incident go before getting out of his patrol car after Rayshard Brooks was found intoxicated asleep at the wheel of his car.

item.title: Roman board game unearthed in Norway burial pit dates back 1,700 years ago
item.description: A complete game set that dates back more than 1,700 years was unearthed in Norway that was played by Romans of significant status. The find includes a dice made of bone and circular pieces.

item.title: The jaw-dropping images that have wowed the judges in the annual Moscow International Foto Awards
item.description: The annual Moscow International Foto Awards is now in its seventh year and has been flooded with entries from photographers in over 100 countries.

item.title: My chaotic mind fizzes with puns and punchlines
item.description: RORY BREMNER: Worst enemy because it's not fun to be disorganised, to take on too much, to begin tasks but not complete them, to be distracted, to lose concentration or to not follow instructions.

item.title: People prefer Niketown to Westminster Abbey
item.description: ROBERT HARDMAN: Still, while this might have been a resounding victory for Mammon over the Almighty, I suppose it does at least offer some badly-needed hope for our threadbare economy.

item.title: Ex-eBay staff 'sent spiders and roaches to harass couple'
item.description: Six former eBay staffers, including top executives, have been charged with conspiracy to commit cyberstalking and tamper with a witness as part of a twisted campaign to terrorize a blogger.

item.title: Women reveal a lockdown silver lining with savings of £12,000 after forgoing beauty treatments
item.description: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to impose restrictions on salons, people across the country will have gone without their go-to beauty treatments for nearly three months.

item.title: Did hospital kill this mother with too much paracetamol?
item.description: Mother-of-two Laura Higginson, from Widnes, Cheshire, passed away in April 2017 aged just 30 after being admitted to hospital with suspected pneumonia.

item.title: Amazon says CEO Jeff Bezos willing to testify before Congress
item.description: Amazon says billionaire founder Jeff Bezos is willing to testify before Congress about potential violations of US antitrust law by big tech companies.

item.title: Autistic lecturer suffering from anxiety wins legal case against private London university
item.description: A university lecturer with special needs has won a discrimination claim after she was overworked by her former employers BPP university in London, which led to her suffering severe anxiety.

item.title: Scientists bring wireless internet underwater for the first time using 'Aqui-fi'
item.description: Scientists have built a system called 'Aqu-fi that brings wireless internet underwater using lasers that transmits content from the diver's smartphone to a computer on the surface in real-time.

item.title: Country singer Hank Williams Jr's daughter dies in car crash
item.description: Katherine Williams-Dunning was killed when her SUV crashed in Tennessee on Saturday. Her sister, Holly Audrey Williams, expressed her shock in an Instagram post on Sunday.

item.title: How iconic Fisher-Price toys have changed over the past century
item.description: Fisher-Price, which was founded in 1930, is celebrating 90 years. The toy company has opened its archives to show how some of its classic toys have changed designs over the decades.

item.title: Boris Johnson holds crunch summit with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen
item.description: After holding a virtual summit, the leaders confirmed that the transition will end in December, and declared talks will be 'intensified' in July in a desperate bid to break the deadlock.

item.title: Doctor Who introduces Rebecca Root as the show's first transgender companion
item.description: Doctor Who has introduced its first transgender companion for the show's new Big Finish audio series Stranded.

item.title: Melania Trump known as 'the portrait' by 'the Princess' Ivanka
item.description: Melania Trump called Ivanka Trump 'the princess' while the First Daughter referred to her as 'the portrait' - because she spoke about as much as one.

item.title: Met Police frogmen search Hyde Park lake for evidence two weeks after 'triple stabbing'
item.description: Police were searching the water of The Serpentine in Hyde Park today as they investigate what was initially treated as a triple stabbing on Saturday, May 30, just as lockdown measures were eased.

item.title: 'This Is Us' writer Jas Waters battled depression for 20 years
item.description: This Is Us writer Jas Waters, 39, took her own life last week, with the LA County Coroner ruling her death a suicide by hanging. She was diagnosed with depression at age 19.

item.title: Pictured: Far-right statue defender surrounded by baying mob - moments before he was rescued
item.description: The man, whose 'life was in danger', can be seen raising his hand to demonstrators before getting dragged into the mob near Waterloo Station, central London, on Saturday.

item.title: Mother horrified after mysterious hornet-like insect with giant 'stinger' is found in their garden
item.description: A giant wasp-like insect was discovered by Samantha, Stoneley, 28, after it fell out of the sky and landed dead in her back garden. Experts believe it to be a harmless wood wasp.

item.title: British firm fires a 6.5ft-long rocket 20,000ft into the air from Shetland
item.description: A 6.5ft (2m) rocket called Skylark Nano blasted off from Fethaland Peninsula on the mainland of Shetland and reached an altitude of around 20,000 ft (6km).

item.title: Any form of healthy eating can lower risk of heart disease, study says
item.description: Any form of healthy eating over several decades can lower the risk of heart disease, according to a new study in the US using data collected over the course of 30 years.

item.title: PG Wodehouse's former Mayfair home on sale for £2.25m
item.description: An apartment in a grand Neo-Baroque blue-plaque Mayfair house, formerly a Royal residence of Alexander Mountbatten, 1st Marquess of Carisbrooke, has gone on sale for £2.25 million.

item.title: Martin Lewis reveals how to save money in five minutes
item.description: Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis, 48, from London, revealed how to save money in five minutes by discovering hidden payments being taken from debit and credit accounts on This Morning.

item.title: Mail on Sunday launches petition over Winston Churchill statue
item.description: The Mail is calling on our readers to help block any attempt to remove the statue of Sir Winston Churchill from outside the Houses of Parliament.
